print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is to hold a standard lathe finished pen for laser etching using awesome T2Lasers rotary tool profiles and a standard eleksmaker A3 laser etcher.
Parts needed to make this one as pictured, 2 x 250mm 3/8 steel rod, 6mm x 270mm threaded rod, motor and connectors to attach to Mana SE and I used a 22mm x 7mm bearing.

You do not need anything like 250mm, I just used that as I had 500mm length sitting around and figured I may want to repurpose it later to something larger.
Uses a cheap 28BYJ-48 motor plugged in to a Y axis plug with the other Y axis motor disconnected, IMPORTANT .. the motor is bipolar modified, pop off the blue plastic cover, cut the centre track connecting the two poles and remove the red centre tap wire.
easy to google .. eg http://www.electronicsmayhem.com/?p=13

I used a 12V version so I had no need to drop motor currents on the stepper driver, resistance is far too high to overheat.
The motor gearbox has some endplay which this rack removes by clamping however gearbox backlash is another issue, this is fine if you want to raster burn but if you want to use vector then you may get some unwanted artifacts.
I set it up in T2laser's Rotary axis setup as 32768 steps/rotation (other models of the motor have different gearing ymmv) and set diameter of work piece, Due to such high number of steps you will likely need to perform a $111=100 to drop Y step rate to something the little motor can handle.
Attached designspark files as usual for remodelling, the little handle is pretty much a joke, might want to add a base. The end support is to stop the weight of the rods pulling the end down if more than half closed, not needed for correct length rods.
I also needed a 6mm tap to get a nice thread and a 3mm drill/tap for the motor mount holes.
I ended up drilling the slider holes out to 10.2mm to make it slide easily. Was just the drill bit I had to hand. Drill 3d printed plastic with the drill running backwards to stop it being torn to pieces by big drills.

If you want to use it to hold something else then create a suitable spindle_pen and bearing_pen to suit your item.

author: GGaNET8

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Dungeon edge corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbors. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Printed in black.  Painted with successive layers of dry brush of grey, tope, and light grey.  Cracks are painted with wider lines of the light grey and a thinner line of black.

Here is my spool wall mount. I wanted to make it to look nice and be sure it wont brake so it is not super filament-saving design but who cares :)

I included STL file to print a bar to put it between mount arms but you can use anything round and max 20mm in diamater (even a part of a broomstick :) )

Yes, arm requires support to print.

For mounting to the wall (drywall in my case) I have used self-drilling drywall achor. It is widely available. Picture show version with two mounting holes at the top but only one is more than enough so STL contain new version with one hole.

So I created my own and was about to upload it and give credit to Gizz when up pops yours... exactly what I needed! I'm not bothering to upload mine now, as I'm sure this would work fine. description.text:
This is a simple enclosure for my Distractify Button. Feel free to check out the project on Github for more info, but the gist of it is that I wanted a button at my desk that someone could press to get my attention rather than tapping me on the shoulder or waving a hand in front of my face.

This is a simple cylindrical enclosure with an opening for a 30mm arcade button and an exit point for a wire.

I originally wanted to use a bayonet-style locking lid, but ended up getting frustrated and settled for using glue to bond the two pieces together. I don't anticipate needing to ever open this thing again.

title: Zero Gravity Extruder Direct Drive by Gudo & Neotko
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Attribution



Gudo, Neotko and IRobertI



Description



ZGE Authors


ZGE Idea and design & development by Charly - Gudo

Crazy Ideas and ZGE Logo by Sebas - Neotko

Much still to write about how to print this, assemble and use it correctly.


Small update. The user Sen from um forum did share this info, sound like a veey interesting source cor precision 4x4 square shaft:

— quote —
I bought it here in Germany from a German reseller:

https://www.gemmel-metalle.de/edelstahl/vierkant/1.4301/edelstahlvierkant-7042.html

It is stainless, 4x4mm, that is one that I found maybe it is also something useful for you. It is made with DIN 178 what should have a pricision of +/- 0,075mm
— quote —

For now Check this OLD VIDEOS (REMEMBER THEY ARE OLD and they show OLD version assembly, but should give some hits to the pro users)



There's a STL with the Whole ZGE Assembled with the ZGE Shorthead, USE that to understand where goes everything.

There are Step files for everything, EXCEPT the Gudo-SliderUJoint system and the ShortZGE main part.

For any question, ask on the forum, not here, otherwise Gudo or I won't be able to answer properly.

Example of BAD Ujoint print

General FAQ


Can I use other bearings?

NO. There's much math and simulations and beta testing on all the parts, if you fell like changing something just to save a buck, then this isn't the extruder for you, sorry!


Can I use a shorter square rod?

NO. I did bang Gudo with this many times, he is just so patient and explained me over and over how and why it can't. Basically that's the correct size for a umo/um2. Can you use 400 instead of 390mm, yea you can. But 390mm is the perfect length so it doesn't pick an eye while moving or hits you, and also is the length that allows the slider part to have always full contact with the square rod. So, like I said before, file the tip, because metal can hurt. (It never ever happened to me and I do look at the printer like a mad men when printing to debug stuff).


Could I move the holder to the other corner?

Yes, print it mirroed (that's something I did ask at the beginning, but after using it on the Left side I would not change it, it just make's sense... Hard to explain..


Can I use a cheaper drivegear?

NO (well you actually could if you redesign most of the stuff, but if you just want to extrude without quality you can do it by hand )


Can I just print it on ABS or PLA, or China cheap PLA?

NO. ABS for example size changes a lot, it can't get as much flex torsion without deforming as platec/greentec. Ofc if you thing you can, just do it, but don't come here asking why it fails Also the material used must be as precise as possible, that something that only good brands give. You wan't to have as many things under- control as possible when printing printing this with a bowden since the tolerances are quite hard. Short answer, we recommend Greentec / Platec for hightemp and strength.


Could I avoid to print the Flexible material parts?

Oh yes, I forgot, there are parts that actually need to be printed on flexible materials like ninjaflex, recreus and a semiflex material. WHY? Just because (will explain all this on the video/tutorial). Most of them you can actually print them after installing the system, but also, well you can print them one by one very slow until you get the zge working


Why the motor holder moves a bit when printing?

Because the system compensates the extrusion forces to avoid as much motion transmission to the printhead. Also, better the motor holder than the printhead, right?
I have a dual printer, I wan't to use this!?


That's actually doable, Gudo even made a design that could work on a UM3. But... More or that someday. Basically we don't want to just make stuff that could work, but stuff that actually put something interesting on the table. There are many factors beyond making the extruder work on a um3 than just making it. Gudo actually I think did cover all of them, but then there's the part of the firmware. The UM3 firmware need's quite a lot knowhow to actually change parameters like Extrusion retraction while changing tools, prime amount, retraction amount, esteps, etc etc etc. So change this parameters on a um3 the user would need to know much knowhow to do stuff on linux without bricking the machine (editing stuff is really easy in the end but is a giant leap for most users). So for now we choose not to, but is there, if UM or maybe a modder makes a easy way to access the Machine Json files and edit them, then we might release it. Just because, it doesn't make sense to release stuff just for releasing stuff. Also, there's a big problemo for flexibles on um3, and that's the gap of air on top of the cores while they rest on the printhead.. So, could it work? Sure, but would it work everytime? That's the question... So, short answer, not yet.
More FAQ And important points about ZGE


Why we made it

Gudo and Neotko are moving forward this extruder because we are always pursuing quality, speed and precision. Bowden is a lightweight solution that creates quite a number of handicaps, like for example hysteresis (filament compression due pressure) making it impossible to actually control the extrusion. With ZGE Direct Drive this is now posible, for 1.75mm filaments and 2.85mm, without any compromise on Extrusion horse power.


Why don’t we sell it atm

Gudo and I (Neotko) have other interest than just selling upgrades. Is a nice idea, but we been crunching numbers and isn’t something we would love to be doing on the short time. I have a business and is starting to work and it demands my full time (except weekends where I try to keep improving every bit of the printer). Also isn’t that easy, to make a comercial version of the ZGE would requiere most probably a mold, and that’s freaking expensive, delivery, stock, gudo making sliders, me printing all the other parts, and that could be a nice dream but we don’t have a 100 printers farm to do it right, and sincerely is great to not need to defend something that you want to 'sell' it keeps the mind objective and fresh to new ideas.


So we have choose the YDIY (You Do It Yourself) path. I will make videos of how to print and assemble the key parts that requiere extreme love and care to do them right. Gudo I think can provide for some individuals the key parts, but don’t overwhelm him, if you don’t get one, you need to DIY.


The good


It freaking works, it extrudes beautifully, it keeps working and working and delivering repetition and amazing precision even with flexibles. Bondtech dualdrive has a lot on that, it could be done with a lesser quality extruder gear, but it would give troubles, bondtech does work and work and work. It grinds a bit, NO, it pushes the filament over and over (and we get Zero commission from bondtech on this!). The system moves a 390mm square shaft of 4mm square. This was the first challenge. I have been testing a 3x3 thinner rod and it works beautifully, but it will only be of use for 1.75mm guys.


1.75mm requieres less heat to extrude, less pressure, but also it has a drawback, it need’s more rotation on the drive gear, this means more stuff moving. That’s why a 3x3mm is better, because it delivers less noise to the weak um head (more on that latter)


2.85mm requieres more heat to extrude, more pressure but also has the advantage of less rotation on the drivegear, this means less noise translated to the printhead, but more force. So for this the best is a 4x4 square shaft.


The Bad


The punny UM2 hotend. We are using a hotend designed specifically for bowden, and bowden has one advantage, remove pressure and movement on the printhead, that’s why any single force done on the printhead (even a wooble bowden shacking) can add noise to the prints. And for the ZGE this means that every rotation on the drivegear can, since the head has very easy to bend and flexible shafts, translate tinny bits on Z noise. Does this Z noise is perceptible? Well, is hard to see, but is there, most users that don’t have a perfect Z might not notice this, but since I’m a crazy guy I did noticed it. The first version was much more dependent of a perfect square shaft. Gudo made an amazing improvement to this problem developing a printable UJoint system that allows to remove the imperfections of a inexpensive rod (more on this later). And just yesterday, I got an idea (star medal for me on this since I’m really proud) we changed a part to be printed on flexible material removing almost 50% of the noise and making the prints look even better.


So... Does it print better than a Bowden? It freaking does. Does it has a bit more of noise on Z? Yes it does, sorry, that’s how things are. UM2 head, even the 8mm shafts can ‘bend’ and they keep wobbling making them very susceptible to Pressure from the drive-gears to the head. Every retract/extrude is a sudden move, that translates this sudden moves to the printhead. But with this last update the problem is hard to see, and most of normal users won’t ever see it.


The Ugly


To print a ZGE you need aprox 5h for the most delicate parts (slider+driveshaft) and they will need some post-processing. Add one hour of assembly for this part, that must be done with love and not by brute force. Also you do need a hightemperature
material, like greentec, platec. Just because this part get’s heat from the bed, so if you print at 60, the air will get there to 35C, and that + extrusion forces = bends. The Extruder head also should be greentec, platec. Is a very amazing material (we also get zero commission on this), but need’s hairspray on the bed and brims, and cleaning. I made a good article about how to add custom brims to the support, read it, read it again, and use it. You need all the parts to be printed perfect. More than 50mm/s can ruin the print and will add time to manual cleaning, that is less reliable than a 3dprinter.
You will need to calibrate your printer to the 0.02-0.03 closeness to the measures we will show as base. Just like Gudo and I did, we used one of the parts, print it and with a digital caliper of at least 2 decimal points, I did print the object 3 times, with different Horizontal Expansion values of -0.02 -0.03 -0.05. For me the winner was the 0.02. So as you can guess, the difference from printing it right or wrong is very very small. You need to keep that in mind for the main part of the ZGE, since is the most delicate part. First time I print one I did it horrible, and after printing 20-23 I thing I have enough practice to make a perfect ZGE slider+shaft.


The rest of the parts, need screws, nothing hard to find. There are two types of heads, one is more compact but need’s some special small 4mm mini shafts. The other, is more complex to assemble and is based on my Neotko-FatIRobertI extruder. Gudo also added a tension selector (very cool) to have 3 basic positions easy interchangeable. But is much complex to print. Also is taller... That... Well, shorter means less vibrations, taller more vibrations... Yea there are many many factors that we have take into account before posting this.


We still need to talk Gudo and I of what basic version we release. Most probably the slider, they key part, won’t have a step file release, but the others might, or not. The important is that all the parts will be easy to print, except the slider (the slider, as I said over and over here must be printed with love and finished more or less by hand).


The Main key parts you will need to get to DIY.

First of all, the square rod of 390mm, there are shops on ebay that cut on demand, but try to be ware that the tip you need to soft it (file it) for safety! You don’t want to loose an eye because you didn’t hear us out right?

For precision square shafts (they call them Key Steel or Parallel Key) the max length we where able to find is 350mm (on misumi) so that means that it would not work. It need’s to be a minimum of 390mm. Gudo might be able to provide this to some users, but again, ask once, if he doesn’t answer he is busy doing something more interesting, don’t hammer it. And you will need to pay for it, you know, square shafts don’t grow on trees.

A shorter smaller screw. You know the four screws that hold your hotend? Well, one must be shorter, like 4mm taller, you can ‘sew’ it yourself indeed. Again, not easy to find. Gudo is amazing and he made me a few with the first kits he made for me.


Bondtech Drive gears for 1.75 or 2.85 you need the 8mm shaft dia, with 4mm -
24-25mm long shaft for the mirror gear.


Motor. I have use, and I keep using, the UMO motor without any geared solution. For 1.75 works perfectly. For 2.85 the best (until one of the beta testers install it and test the motor I sent) is a Bondtech 5.18 geared nema. It works and works.


I have a shop, I want to sell it!


Contact Gudo for this, you two might get along and do some business. I personally would love to see this extruder on every printer out there. But mind one thing, no shortcuts, no china quality. If you thing you are decent, come talk with Gudo.


I want it for my printer!


Our dream is to have this on as many printers as possible, a Bowden-free world. If you are a 3d printer maker contact us and we will study making a version of our ZGE for your machine. But remember this is Open Source, so we will focus on Open Source machines like UM, BCN, and probably others.


If we don’t support your printer, give us time, we are just two guys that love 3d printing and making our printers as precise as possible. Contact your printer company, if they give us access to your files we might do it! And ofc if you have a Solid Robust No Woobly printer, we are interested But ofc, Maybe Gudo just make's a better printer out of this UM.... But that's a history for other day


Materials and methods




ZGE BOM LIST

  • BONDTECH Dual Gears kit 1.75mm or 2.85mm/shaft dia 8mm
  • important if use

    Iroberti order the 4mm x 22mm driven gear pin

    Short ZGE order the 4mm x 25mm driven gear pin
  • 4x4mm precision Square Rod - Steel or Stainless steel - 390/400 mm lenght
  • ZGE Bearings

    8x - 3x8x3 ZZ (slider)

    2x - 8x16x5 ZZ (extruder)

    2x - 10x19x5 ZZ (frame motor holder)

    2x - 12x21x5 ZZ (print head extruder holder)
  • Fastener metric M3 SOCKET HEAD BOLTS & NUTS


  • ADJUSTABLE FRAME MOTOR HOLDER

    2x 20mm (UM2 frame)

    2x 18mm (UMO frame)

    2x 8mm + nut

    1x 35mm + nut
  • MOTOR SHAFT/SQUARE ROD COUPLER

    4x 12mm + M3 nut
  • STEPPER MOTOR HOLDER

    4x 10mm

    3x 16mm + nut
  • SLIDER

    10x 18mm + nut
  • GEAR DRIVE SHAFT

  • EXTRUDER

  • 3x 8mm Hexagon socket button head (or Philips equivalent)

  • SHORT version

    1x 30mm + nut

    1x 35/40 mm HEXAGONAL head + nut

comments.text:
I didn't really read through the description and comments, so excuse if me if it has been already addressed.
Generally I like the design very much, I've been thinking about something similar in theory for a long time. I see that You've gone to great length to make the torque transfer smoother on the extruder side.
Have you ever considered or try to deliver the power through two rods rotating in opposing directions? That would hopefully eliminate the effect that applying torque tries to twist the whole extruder assembly. I guess that it could improve the handling of retractions.
It's unique and interesting btw.
comments.author: mhejjas

comments.text: Thanks
comments.author: mhejjas

comments.text: Don't quite get what special use case this is supposed to be for. If you don't want any weight on the print head, just use a bidden bowden extruder. Otherwise this just looks super over complicated and more of a "solution looking for a problem" sort of thing. Looks cool though.
comments.author: HikariNoKitsune

comments.text: bowden cant extrudes as precisely as direct. and result bad quality prints (regardless your motion system)
comments.author: HikariNoKitsune

comments.text: Basically is to use full size stepper motors on a directdrive without the problem of adding 250grms (bondtech for example) on the top of the printhead.
comments.author: HikariNoKitsune

comments.text:
Not clear how it deals with gravity (joke)
Actually the extruder weight is only increased with at least half of the rode (actually more since the free end of the rod continues longer behind the head) and additional plastic connectors weight, since it is just secured on the top of the original head.
In addition, for high speed printing the important counter factor is not only weight itself, but also mass of the head and the moving rods. For higher quality print at high speed the head must stop where the controller think it has to stop. But due to inertia of mass the head continue its movement a bit further. This lowers precision adn quality of the print. So the construction with higher overall mass head has higher inertia and lower quality of print.
I would prefer use of Bowden (remote) drive for plastic. Just choose teflon tube of 2mm internal diameter for 1.75mm plastic.
comments.author: alex_belov

comments.text: Indeed, there's inertia, most of the weight is translated, specially if you use the bondtech motor that weights more than the one I use, to the motor. The inertia ofc is there.

author: Gepetto

description.text:
Spareparts for Nissan 350Z V6 Engine for restauration and furniture

This is the result of a hobby project of mine. I bought an old V6 engine to create a table from it but I wasn't really happy with the block itself so I redesigned the piston assembly. I bought it with the crankshaft and some pistons (thought I might make the feet out of them now) and had to realise that they won't fit propperly after a paintjob - of course not, but the block had to be repainted to look good and prevent rust in the cylinders.
So I 3d printed the pistons and reassembled the engine, now it looks cooler I think and it "works" again.

In the future I might attach something like a stepper motor to the output shaft to create a mighty fidget spinner haha

  • Rod can be screwed together with M3x30 or longer
  • Piston is made a little bit smaller to fit after the block has been painted
  • The package includes a crankshaft clamp because I think it's very ugly to reuse the
    lower engine body.
  • I made some stands too for M8 threaded rod, cut it about 50mm the hole is 40mm deep
  • I recommend printing the loosefit version because the normal version is very accurate and
    may cause problems while assembling

I roughly designed the parts by using original dimensions, it's not perfectly the same and designed to have better printing results.

title: AIO FPV Groundstation / Video-Tester for 5" LCD

description.text:
This is an enclosure for a compact FPV monitor-receiver unit. It is supposed to be equipped with a common 5" monitor and the DIY rx5808-pro-OSD receiver: https://github.com/markohoepken/rx5808_pro_osd.
To control the receiver, use the band scanner, etc., there are 3 holes to fit standard push buttons like SCI R13-24A1-05-BK or similar.
As power on/off switch I am using Marquardt 1801.6115, but there should also be others with equivalent installation size available.

The back cover features openings for a BEC- and a XT60-connector, so different types of batteries can be used, depending on what's lying around and still has some mAh inside :)
Furthermore, I made the second video-input accessible, first with a 3-pin male-servo-connector (for direct connection of FPV cams to change settings, adjust focus, etc.) and second with a common cinch connector.
There's also a provision to fit a D=12mm piezo buzzer for a low voltage alarm.
And last but not least, there are two slots for a battery strap and a 5,1mm bore on the bottom to cut a 1/4" UNC thread to bolt it onto a camera tripod.

Connect the additional video-in-sockets both in parallel to the monitor's input with higher priority. That way it will show the signal from the internal receiver normally and automatically switch to the aux-input, if there's a signal detected.

If you want the LCD settings to be easily available, you can use nylon bolts M3x15 as plungers. Insert them from the inside of the enclosure, so that their heads touch the LCD buttons when you press on the other end.

Con el diseño actual no se pueden usar varillas de 12mm para el Eje Y, 10mm es el tamaño máximo.

NOTA 18/10/2017: he añadido algunas piezas para poder usar varillas de 10 mm, y algunas piezas para poder incluir finales de carrera.

También he añadido un soporte para la Makita RT0700C aunque todavía no está probado.

Hola os presento mi nueva Máquina CNC, aun estamos en proceso de construcción pero ya podemos compartirla.

Es una máquina que se puede imprimir en 3d casi en su totalidad y ha sido diseña con el sofware Freecad.

Para la información de montaje podéis pasaros por mi web http://www.srferrete.es , encontrareis listas de materias, acceso a los ficheros freecad y más cosas.

title: OpenForge Smooth Edge Dead End Tiles

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Dungeon edge dead end tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
The smooth set can be used for any number of things. Look at the Smooth floor tile set for ideas. There, I've done concrete, ice and dirt. Here I've done concrete.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbors. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
Compatible tiles/walls in this series are tagged with OpenForge
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Printed in black.  Painted with successive layers of dry brush of grey, tope, and light grey.  Cracks are painted with wider lines of the light grey and a thinner line of black.

title: Wanhao Duplicator 7 Vat Covers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a set of vat covers (top and bottom) for the stock Wanhao Duplicator 7 resin vat. I made these because it seemed easier than cleaning all the vat out so i could tinker with the printer.

there are two versions of the bottom plate, one with printed threads, and one with holes for M6x50 bolts. NOTE: i have not tested the bolts version for fit, on account of i don't have any bolts but it prints okay

The printed thread version works, though definitely make sure your printer is up to scratch accuracy-wise.

title: Fan Shroud For ED3 head on MonoPrice Mini

description.text: This is a mashup for people using an E3D print head on the MonoPrice Select Mini, although it could probably be used on any printer with an E3D print head.The mashup was made by removing the MP Select mount from Sonsum's design and cutting in Poken1151's E3D mount. The E3D mount was resized to fit a heat sink diameter of 28mm. ( My E3D head is a china knockoff so I wouldn't be surprised if it's smaller than the original.) This design fits the original MPS mini fan that came with the printer. Stl files edited with Turbocad and gcoded in Cura.

updated STL

Had some unwanted "slots" show up during the print. should be fixed now.

title: Rabbit Extruder (Tavşan ekstruder) with press-idler system

description.text:
TR:

Kendi yazıcımda 1 aydır kullanıyorum. Tamamen benim dizaynım olup ana gövde dizaynında aşağıdaki dizayndan esinlendim:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579394
Bu ekstruder'de Wade's ekstruder dizaynı ve benzer dizaynlardaki çift vidalı ve çekme-pimli sistem yerine mk8 ekstruder dizaynı gibi basma-pimli bir sistem geliştirdim.
Video:
https://youtu.be/4VuweZZcqJs

EN:

I have been using this extruder on my printer for about one month. It is completely my design but only when designing the main body I inspired from this design:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1579394
In this design, I aimed to design a press-idler system like in mk8 extruders rather than a pull-idler system with two long screws like used in wade's extruder and other similar designs.

Printer:

Hypercube

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

30

Notes:

TR:

Tüm parçalar %30 dolgu ile basılabilir. Yalnızca Idler parçası %50 dolguda ve mümkünse katmanlar arası tutuculuğun daha fazla olduğu PLA veya PETG ile basılmalı.

EN:

All parts except the idler can be printed in 30% infill. Idler should be printed in 50% infill minimum and also in PLA or preferably in PETG which have a greater inter-layer adhesion.

Gerekli Malzemeler (Required items)
  • 1x 623ZZ (3x10x4) ---> Idler
  • 2x 693ZZ (3x8x4) ----> Idler - Ana gövde bağlantısı için. Bu rulmanı kullanmaksızın yapılabilecek ana gövde modeli de mevcuttur (for connection between idler and body. There is also another body model which can be used without these bearings)
  • 2x MF105ZZ (5x10x4)
  • 1x 20mm extruder - tabla yayı (Extruder spring)
  • Çeşitli boylarda m3 vida ve somunlar (m3 screws in various sizes and nuts)
  • m5x50 civata (mümkünse yarım paso) ve somun (m5x50 hex bolt (half threaded if possible)and nut)
  • 180mm GT2 kapalı kayış, başka boyut denemedim ama en fazla bu olabiliyor (180mm gt2 belt, I haven't tried other sizes so give it a try)
    NOT: Dişlilerde merkezler arası mesafe en az 46, en fazla da 52mm'dir (Inter-gear length is minimum 46mm, maximum 52mm)
    http://www.bbman.com/belt-length-calculator/
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/180-GT2-loop-timing-belt-width-6mm-GT2-belt-Rubber-Fiberglass-inner-length-180mm-90teeth-for/32763966796.html
  • gt2 16t kasnak, 20t de olabilir(gt2 16t pulley, can be 20t)
  • 1x mk7 extruder gear (5mm inner hole, 12mm outer diameter and 13.3mm height)
    I bought the gears from here:
    https://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-Parts-Stainless-Steel-MK7-Extruder-Drive-Gear-Bore-5mm-For-1-75mm-Hobbed-Gear/32669411295.html
Designed with SpaceClaim but a DesignSpark file is also added.

29.05.17: 68T ve 74T GT2 kasnak eklendi (68T and 74T GT2 pulleys are added)
30.05.17: 693ZZ rulman kullanmadan yapılabilecek şekilde ana gövde modeli eklendi (Body without 693ZZ is added if you don't want to use those little bearings)

print_settings.Notes:: Printed at 40mm/s with a shell thickness of 2mm. Supports placed on all overhangs but adjusted supports to be easier to remove due to the space in the battery compartment. Support details: structure-lines, overhang angel for support-45, fill amount - 10%, distance x/y - .7, distance z - .22. You may be able to have more support it will just be harder to remove and this looks to do it well enough. Used high infill to be more structurally sound to handle getting hit by paintballs and not break.

title: Invert Halo Too hopper battery cover

description.text: Replacement and upgraded battery cover for the Invert Halo Too Paintball Hopper. I added a storage place for the 9v battery so you can get rid of the battery movement while playing. It will be a few more weeks until I am able to test this in action on the field but I believe it will hold up very well to being shot (better than the original at least). You will have to put the battery in so that the wires leave away from the cover. Is an overall good fit but not quite as perfect rounded edges as the original one. The lip at the end you may have to pay close attention to removing the supports so that it slides onto the hopper smoothly. I made the front near the screw just slightly thicker than the original and rounded it over so there would be slightly more plastic to be stronger. If you have any suggestions or if you have one break in action please let me know so I can adjust.

Printer:

Trinus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

50

Notes:

Printed at 40mm/s with a shell thickness of 2mm. Supports placed on all overhangs but adjusted supports to be easier to remove due to the space in the battery compartment. Support details: structure-lines, overhang angel for support-45, fill amount - 10%, distance x/y - .7, distance z - .22. You may be able to have more support it will just be harder to remove and this looks to do it well enough. Used high infill to be more structurally sound to handle getting hit by paintballs and not break.
Designed with Autodesk Fusion 360 and sliced with Cura.

author: blaizu

description.text:
This plane was supposed to fly at Inter-Ex 2016 in Versoix/Geneva. http://jivaro-models.org/interex_2016/index.html
This is a meeting where you see objects flying which seem to be unflyable :-)

This model is more for fun than to be a sophisticated aerodynamic airplane.
You must have a lot of expierence to be able to ride this crazy horse.
We had to try out several CG points and trimm settings for the elevons.
Finally it flew but something happened that caused the crash. Luckily there was a rapeseed field...
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9iDHNIykRQ
Except of the front fuselage all has remained unhurt.

As next I will try a different shape of the elevons and set them more backwards.
Then we will try it again :-)

title: Filament Tube holder for MakerGear M2

I created a tube holder for the extruder end that screws to the open fan hole with an M3 screw.

author: GreatExcelcior

print_settings.Notes:: "gate - chevron amber x9" are the chevrons lights and should be printed white or clear.

description.text:
This design is a replica of the SGC's Stargate and its ramp. It has been simplified to accommodate smaller printers but remains fairly screen-accurate.

The gate itself has a 117mm(4.6") diameter and has been successfully scaled up to 250mm.

I provide the 123D files of my design if you want to modify it (for example to scale the stepper motor hole in the gear if you wish to print a bigger version).

Assembly:
Please use the exploded views I provided as reference, it is very straightforward.

Electronics:
At the moment I did not write instructions regarding the electronics, but I made a part list and include the arduino sketch if you're willing to attempt it yourself. Note: if you're printing a bigger/thicker version, you could use regular LEDs instead of surface mount.

Parts:

  • 7 surface mount red LEDs
  • 4 surface mount white LEDs
  • 2 or more blue LEDs
  • ULN2803 (or equivalent)
  • 28YBJ-48 stepper motor
  • Any Arduino that fits in the base (I used a mini)
  • Momentary switch (I used a lever switch)
  • 28 awg or smaller wire

Printer:

Monoprice Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I recommend supports for the following parts, the rest doesn't need any support:
gate - back x1
gate - front x1

I strongly recommend using "Support Interface" in Cura for "gate - back" because it provides a better finish for the symbols to rotate in the rail.

"gate - chevron amber x9" are the chevrons lights and should be printed white or clear.

PS: I use a MK8-Wheel with 9mm Diameter and constructed it for this size. Didn´t tested it with a 8mm wheel. If you tested it, let me know if it works too,

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS! Check back to find additions.
Based on the Star Wars pod racers but imagined in a more refined way.
The engines and winglets are from Bold Designs "Margos Dog Eddie" with the wings shortened for the main wings and resized for the front spoiler.
Designed on 123D Design.
Some parts require support.
I printed the canopy then shrunk a plastic bottle over it to make a clear canopy, hence I've supplied a pilot if you want to go this route. Otherwise just paint the canopy black.
I haven't include any registration holes or pins so its up to you how you attach parts.
Also the rear fin top pin wouldn't print due to it's small diameter so I used a barbeque stick.
Model comes out at about 400mm long and will fit most print beds.
I use a CTC makerbot clone.

title: Anet A8 Upgraded Power Supply (12V 30A) Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A quick and dirty design for an upgraded Anet A8 Power Supply (12V 30A) using a fused 110V socket with switch (fits https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00ME5YAPK). Quick and dirty because the 3 small screw holes on the side of the cover and one on the bottom for the 12V wires will need to be drilled by hand. You will need to drill new holes in the Anet A8 frame as this power supply doesn't use the same, existing hole distances of the stock supply.

I recommend using a 2mm or greater spacer between frame and power supply (3 screws) to keep some airflow going between the power supply and the frame and to clear the 2mm thick wall on the back of the cover.

Enjoy!
Frank / AB0WV

author: SO3D

description.text:
The Crossfire 2 is here. Everything you loved about the original but simpler, stronger and easier to build. The original Crossfire has been out in the wild and flying for about a year now and I couldn't be more happy with the interest in this project. Special thanks are in order to all those who printed, tested, flew and remixed this thing. The open source community is incredible and I am proud to share the Crossfire 2 with you. As always please print, fly and enjoy. Feedback, makes and remixes are always appreciated. If you like my designs a small donation is greatly appreciated, it allows me to keep posting cool things! Check out this video for some motivation. https://vimeo.com/79370836 Fpvlab.com Thread:
http://fpvlab.com/forums/showthread.php?25717-3D-Printed-Crossfire-2&p=433303#post433303 So what is new with the Crossfire 2? In general, a lot! It looks like the same ol' Crossfire but its not. I took a lot of feedback on improving the design and I believe I have addressed the major ones. -The Arms: The arms landing gear on the old crossfire was weak. I designed it to be light but it ended up being too brittle. The new arms have been beefed up and strengthened in the weakest areas. It is still very light and I believe it now to be the perfect mix of strength to weight. Also the arms have been designed to have M3 lock nuts press fit in. This standardizes the hardware for the quadcopter and allows easy attachment of the arms. It also allows to top or bottom plates to be easily removed allowing access to the center of the frame. -The frame: As mentioned above the Crossfire 2 has been standardized to M3 hardware. The frame has also been modified to receive any type of flight controller. The standard flight controllers (KK Blackboard, KK2.1) can now be mounted directly to the frame in either 45 deg. or orthogonal orientation. On top of that the Crossfire is designed to be optimized for the APM controller by mounting to the frame via vibration dampening bushings. Using this setup, without any balancing of the props whatsoever give more than adequate vibration dampening. See attached graph, vibrations are roughly half of what 3DR says are tolerances. The frame has been standardized to the vibration dampening camera mount system. Everyone is mounting cameras to their quads these days even if they are not FPV and this is definitely the best way to go to get clean video. Lastly I have added extra holes in the frame to accommodate easier wire routing depending on your setup. Also there are new standoff holes to mount the top cover. -The Top Cover: The top cover has been modified to mount the APM 2.6's GPS/Compass module. Donate Update 2/23/14: I have uploaded the .SKP files for those who want to remix the design. Update 2/13/14: I have added links in the instructions for an explanation on motor kv and a calculator to help run some numbers on motor and prop combinations. A lot of people have been asking about this, and its still a bit of a mystery to me even after building a bunch of multicopters. I hope this helps. Update 2/1/14: I have added batter strap slots to the Bottom Plate for battery straps. If you are not planning on having a camera or vibration dampening battery tray you can now strap your battery directly to the Bottom Plate.

See the attached PDF for a build log and instructions. At the infill settings I've published the frame weighs 400 grams with everything. Thats the 4 arms, the hardware, the Top and Bottom Plates, the Top Cover and the Battery Tray along with the vibration dampening bushings. The arms weigh 38 grams, so thats about 12 grams lighter than the DJI arms. The whole frame together weighs 400 which is 120 grams heavier than the DJI Flamewheel but they don't take into account the hardware weight to put everything together. Those numbers along with the weight of all your equipment will decide what motors, props and ESCs you go with. The one pictured weighs 1700 grams (GoPro3, gimbal, brushless motors, props, FPV equipment, APM and a 4000 may battery. Arms: So far there are two arms uploaded. ArmTall3H - Standard re-enforced arm with a tall leg and 3 hole mounts for the motor. ArmTall4H - Standard re-enforced arm with a tall leg and 4 hole (16x19mm) mounts for motor. For the Vibration Dampening Battery Trays see thing here, there are 4 different options to suit your needs. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239594 Here are a couple links that explain motor kv and a calculator to help with choosing the right electronics and prop combinations.
http://www.flyelectric.com/ans.kv.html
http://www.ecalc.ch/xcoptercalc.htm?ecalc&lang=en

comments.text: Very nice design, but I'd like to make a suggestion (that's simple to implement).  On the arms there are those recessed nut traps that require turning on support material printing.  I'm okay with that, but the latest version of Slic3r insists on supporting the bottom of the landing skids as well (rather than using bridging even though "don't support bridges" is checked) thereby wasting lots of plastic.  My suggestion would be instead of requiring support for the recessed part, create a single layer bridge over the hole that can easily be drilled (or punched) out.  The model will have the screw hole closed off on the bottom (past the recess), but the closed part will only be one layer thick.  I think you'd have much more consistent results with all different kinds of slicers that way.  Just a suggestion.
comments.author: sheck626

comments.text: Hi Mikey (and whoever else might read this) - i'm in a bit of a pickle, namely a tight budget and the question about flight controllers (it is very important that i have autopilot). Can you please give me your opinion about:
comments.author: borisy

comments.text: The KK2.0 board is actually very easy to use and setup if.  I am definitely a fan of the APM. It is an incredible flight controller and autopilot, that being said I have flown planes with systems that took less studying to understand than the APM.  However it is fairly user friendly and very powerful.  A good middle of the road controller (not an autopilot) is the Open Pilot CC3D board.  Very easy to setup and tune and can be expanded into an autopilot with the addition of a gps.  Personally I think whatever gets you in the air the quickest/simplest and cheapest is the right way to go for now.  Quadcopters are a steep learning curve, and if you are going for an autopilot capable controller right out of the gate it is a very steep learning curve.  Just my two cents.
comments.author: borisy

comments.text:
Thank you - thank really helped. I met with local RC hobby group and i asked their opinion about 3d printed copter frame and they were all quite sceptic. I understand that it's hard to compare 3d printed plastic with aluminium, but i won't be racing my drone - it'll spend it's life flying around slowly and taking photoes so i don't think the arms will break mid flight, however they did mention that printed frames tend to vibrate more which distorts the image. They recommended using these two frames -
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__34236__Hobbyking_X580_Glass_Fiber_Quadcopter_Frame_w_Camera_Mount_585mm.html
http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__22732__Turnigy_H_A_L_Heavy_Aerial_Lift_Quadcopter_Frame_585mm.html
comments.author: MikeyB

comments.text: Also, if vibrations still end up being a problem, you could mount the cameras on vibration plugs. On the MHQ2 the whole layer with the flightboard, cameras, Rx, etc is mounted on 6 vibration plugs. You could make something that seperates the gimbal or camera from the body with vibe plugs.
comments.author: borisy

comments.text: In my experience printed frames don't vibrate any more than metal or carbon fibre frames.  Vibration almost has everything to do with unbalanced props.  No matter what frame you use if your props are out of balance you will get vibrations that can give your video jello and play havoc with your flight controller. Printed frames are actually quite strong, definitely won't break mid-flight even with aerobatic flying.  The one huge advantage is that printed frames can be quite a bit lighter than other options and that directly correlates to flight times.  Another is that you won't have to order replacement parts when you (Inevitably) crash, you just print one out.  Check out my battery tray and gimbal. They are designed to dampen vibrations using rubber bushings and the video you get will be crystal clear.
comments.author: borisy

comments.text:
Hey Tim,
I haven't printed anything out in PLA. It seems like PLA may be a little bit heavier? 52 grams is still pretty light, what you are aiming for is that the arms have as little flex as possible. If you can get away with less infill and still get good rigidity then you are golden. If the arm has too much flex the flight controller will have a hard time compensating and the quad will become very unstable. Hope that helps.
comments.author: TimJones

comments.text: Hi, PLA it is little heavier (more density material), but also more rigid, i printed out arms at 35% infill and it is flying very well. Tested with APM2.6 and KK2.1 boards

I'm noticing some stringing with the PLA (image below) which I noticed before but thought it was the ABS. This stringing could be what was causing the layer adhesion issues. I think there might be a blockage in my extruder.
comments.author: MikeyB

comments.text: It could be a blockage in your extruder, but it doesn't look like that to me.  Every time i get stringiness its because my bed is just a little too far away.  The lower arm in the picture (the one being printed) really makes me think that you need to bring the bed up a little bit.  Can you level the bed while you are printing?  Just keep raising it until you have a nice flat bead and you can see any of the bed after the first layer is filled in.
comments.author: cliffmu

comments.text: The first lay comes out exactly that way, nice and flat with full coverage. I like to keep the bed close for the first layer for proper adhesion. This is making me think it could be a setting in Cura. I modified the printer head sizes to 0 so I could print both arms on one platform. I'll try doing another test print when I get back later.

comments.text: They will be a little bit tight, you will have to "flare" them out a bit with an exacto.  The tapered side of the locknuts need to be facing into the center of the arms on the outside holes (if that makes sense) and they will need to be tapped in with a hammer.  Mine went in with one swift tap.  It's the nuts towards the inside of the frame that are a bit tricky because they go in with the flat side facing the top of the arm.  Where did you get your locknuts from?  I got mine from Hobbyking, I will go check the dimensions of mine when I get home.

comments.text: How did you go about choosing the different motors? Every time I start looking at available options for equipment on these, I'm just swamped!
comments.author: jimlee

comments.text: Haha thats a slippery slope. There are many different combinations that work. Basically the more expensive the motor the better. The windings, number of poles, kv rating etc. I really don't have a great understanding of how it all ties in but basically the lower kv motors the more efficient they are. They are also lower power so finding the correct prop combination is key. The bigger the props the longer it takes them to "spool" up and down. A slow turning, big prop is more efficient than a small prop spinning fast but the flight controller has a hard time controlling props that lag a long time behind the inputs. I guess what I'm saying is that this is all a bit of black magic (its not, I'm sure and aeronautical engineer can explain it better) but there is always a little experimentation involved. An motor listed on Hobby King or websites like http://GetFPV.comGetFPV.com under multi-rotors will all work. They should have a listing for what prop size and what size airframe they will be best on. Also forums on multi-copters have LONG threads on combinations, it might be more reading than you are interested in but you might find some good info. Good luck! Let me know what you end up going with.
comments.author: jimlee

comments.text: Hey! Thanks for this design... I'm printing as I type this. I just wanted to make mention of your comment about a lower KV motor being less power... In actuality, the lower the KV the more torque the motor has. So to swing a big prop and not have the lag you mentioned you would actually want a lower KV motor. KV = RPM per Volt. So, how many times will the motor spin after it consumes one volt of electricity. On my current hex setup, I'm using some 530 KV pancake motors in combination with APC slow fly 14 x 4.8 props. This is a large setup and it easily carries a full size DSLR camera. This is a pretty good explanation: http://www.flyelectric.com/ans.kv.htmlhttp://www.flyelectric.com/ans... . Also, someone mentioned eCalc, in case you didn't know, here is a link to xcopterCalc: http://www.ecalc.ch/xcoptercalc.htm?ecalc&lang=enhttp://www.ecalc.ch/xcoptercal... which is a version of eCalc specifically for multicopters.

title: BFB 3D Touch & 3000 Snap-on Fan Ducts - Simple Design

description.text:
Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33494 Final uploads: 27 January 2014
(If you downloaded before that date you don't have the latest and greatest revisions.) What they are...
Two snap-op fan ducts for the BFB 3D Touch and BFB 3000 printer. (Not tested for clearances on the BFB 3000.) One duct fits a single fan and the other fits two side-by-side fans. On a 3-head 3D Touch there are three 60mm fans, two on the front of the carriage and one on the back. I'm not sure if there is always a single fan per extruder head on models with one or two heads, but the single and dual ducts have it covered regardless. My goal was to make these fan ducts completely snap-on and printable without support. After some trial and error I came up with this fairly simple design that snaps nicely and firmly into place. The walls are just 1mm thick all around, so they don't use up much material. I tried adding snap-on deflectors at the outlets of the ducts that would tend to force the airflow down toward the tip of the hot ends, but after trying it with and without them, I decided not to use them. Files included: .stl and .sldprt. One of the .stl files contains both ducts for printing both at a time.

Print 'em. Printed on blue tape.
Layers: 0.25mm
Fill: 20%
Extra Skins: 2
First Layer Temp: 220C
Remaining Layers Temp: 195C Snap 'em on.
Two small bumps, one each on the inside top of the two front corners ('front' means the side opposite the duct outlet), act as detents, mating with the screw holes on the corners of the fans. A small tab on the duct rides against the bottom of the fan body to hold the bumps in the fan hole 'detents'. I have no idea yet what effect these ducts will have on printing, but the theoretical increase in part cooling should reduce warping.

comments.text:

My fans are 60mm x 60mm x 25mm.
looking at the pics i think you have mounted smaler fans.

i used ordered the motors from china :https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-K827-480-Double-Ball-Bearing-Micro-DC-Motor-Short-Shaft-7-2V-18000rpm-Compensating-Carbon/32737825255.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.nLWF9W
i control this thing with a arduino and a relay to switch te motors

the arduino code is in the txt file

you can find more details on my website thijsluiten.nl

i hope you guys can use it for your own projects

description.text:
Update: added the main and locking pin stl file with my attempt at a hair pin clip! the file name is holderpins-v3.stl and Hairpin-v2.stl

My first design, so be kind its still a work in progress. But basically I got annoyed with having to take the screws out every time i wanted to switch the legs on my phantom to accommodate to different situations. So i designed this so:

  1. so it's easier to pack and go
  2. so i can just pull a pin and switch the legs
  3. Cause i created my own design and made it yet

v1 isn't uploaded but it worked it was just bulky so i skipped to v3 of the holder and i'm still working on slimming it down.

also the holding pin works for now but i suggest using a screw, and for the secondary locking pin my end goal is to put a set of ball bearings and a spring in it so it snaps to lock, but currently something similar to size will do, also i havent had to need for it yet since it just locks into place without it.

I'm currently designing smaller feet and feel free to make your own feet as well.

This is still a work in progress.

medium to high

description.text:
This is a flower pot I designed for my wife when she brought home a bunch of small plants.
There are holes in the bottom of each of the cavities, and there are also holes between the cavities to aid in drainage in case one hole becomes clogged.

The drip tray has the same outline as the planter, and the planter locks into the drip tray at four points on the underside, so they won't easily separate when bumped or pushed.

I think it looks great when printed in wood PLA. It just gives it that adobe/clay look that looks great with a succulent in it.

I designed it in SolidWorks and included the SLDPRT files in case anyone wants to edit it.

Sorry about the poor color in the photos. I just wanted to get this posted so I could go do some work in the yard while the weather is nice.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

No

No

0.2mm

20% Cubic

Notes:

I used a brass nozzle and had to replace the nozzle after finishing this print. I would definitely consider getting a hardened nozzle if you want to print more than one before changing nozzles.

title: Tactile Montessori Letters, and Word Game

description.text:
Used for word-forming games. The numbers in the file names indicate how many of each letter to print for the full 117 tile English-French set with weighted quantities.

These are lower case cursive tiles inspired by Montessori sandpaper letters. Have the learner trace the letter properly as they hear or use its sound. There are hundreds of connected activites online, some listed below.

Has french letters é and è. (Accented e's).

I print 4 tiles per print job, each 2mm x 2 inch x 2.5 inch. The holder included holds 1 to 4 tiles.

I used sharpie to color the letters. You can pause and switch filament. The hollow form of the letters start at 1mm. Montessori methods suggest one color for the vowels and a second, contrasting color for the consonants.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7ACryOvm0fM

THANK YOU for your interest, and for sharing your improvements.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm / layer, 7 layers

Infill:

0%
CCSS

The word game is used to form words, to learn to feel for the relative importance of each letter, adding for younger learners, and keeping score and fair play for older learners. 
The montessori sandpaper letters are used to help the learner internalize the shapes of letters, as a precurser to writing.

New learners: http://happyhooligans.ca/scrabble-tiles-for-learning/ More experienced learners: http://insights-into-tefl.blogspot.ca/2008/10/games-to-play-with-scrabble-letters.html Montessori exercices: http://www.infomontessori.com/language/written-language-sandpaper-letters.htm
Full set as printed.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
A much smaller version here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357657

Update:
I extended the sides where the LM2596 is placed.

YouTube: https://youtu.be/wc3J8u5KAgE

This is a solar controller that can turn an 18v or 20v solar panel input into a 12v output utilizing the LM2596 DC-DC step-down. I design this for a Raspberry PI 3 with a 7-inch monitor to run on strictly solar power but can be used for other devices as well.

LM2596 how to adjust voltage: https://youtu.be/s7_B0LqUKuM

LM2596:
Input: 3v - 40v
Output: 1.5v - 35v
Maximum output amps: 3 amps

Fan:
50mm X 50mm X 11mm
12v
uses about .03 amps - .04 amps

Push on/off button:
3 amp button

I used a 30-watt solar panel and at the highest daylight output, I made adjustments to the Lm2596. I set the LM2596 from 19 v to 12.6 volts. Different solar panels may have different output volts so adjust accordingly. Remember the LM2596 has a max amp output of 3 amps so make sure you don't go over or you will overheat the chip. I used a 3D Pen to make the plug stronger and to set the LM2596 in place. I can use a hot air gun to remove if I need to.

I designed a case for one that can handle 15 amps: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2357678

This little guy simply converts your Vapor2 unit into a pen like smoke machine. I built it to test airflow structure in my cooling fan assemblies.

Build notes:
→ This thing is intentionally 1/10th of a mm too small, it needs to be air tight so lightly sand the interior until it fits snugly.
→ The tube push button should be one of the 10mm (9.80 and change ) thread sizes.
→ Do remember to load the unit with pure VG, otherwise who knows what's going to be left on your parts.
→ Pop in a tube and blow smoke into whatever you need to see airflow passing.
→ Profit.

title: greg's guidler with safe print breakaway

description.text: The little halfmoon shape thingi that is supposed to hold the bridge for the beginning of the hinge was seriously getting on my nerves, I mean really! yes Really! five prints that thing keeps getting unstuck. also the sharp corner holding the bearing tended to curl up a bit. So I thought time to do something about it!. IOtherwise it's just like the greg's guildler just cut the stuff off when the print is done, I might adjust this a little bit right now it's being held by the main body maybe a bit much, After some test prints I might adjust it a bit, but the bridge is already done on my first print I just dunno how serious the cutting will be wastes less plastic than a full raft I will adjust on the fly and might not mention it till finalized

for j-head it's already in stl, otherwise just use the open scad file with the other files from the original greg's guildler (only the main scad file is modified) get the rest of the files here
print cut the stuff after and enjoy a more secure print :)
you can adjiust the mounts in the openscad file just like with greg's no difference except for my securement :)
update: I adjusted the holding breakaway piece slightly and made it thinner as well I might add some holes in it later I dunno yet
Use xacto knife or sharp swiss army knife on bearing tip stick :)
Happy Reprapping :)
terramir

comments.text: Very cool improvements! I was sharing your frustration. I've very happy that you did this. I'll post some print pics soon.

description.text:
The Spoolholder supplied with the Fabrikator mini V2 was unusable with the most Spools that i owned. The Spools scratched the stepper or didnt fit at all. So i designed anoter one.

Two versions:
One without pitch.
One with pitch to keep the spool close to the printer. Some slender Spools tend to slowly move away from the printer and one time the Filament slipped out of the Spool. The 2 degrees picht should avoid that.

Deutsch:
Der Spulenhalter der mit dem Fabrikator mini V2 mitgeliefert wurde war für die meisten meiner Spulen unbrauchbar. Die Spulen schleiften am Schrittmotor oder passten gar nicht rein.

Es gibt zwei Versionen:
Eine mit Neigung und eine Ohne.
Einige dünnere Spulen tendieren dazu sich vom Drucker mit der Zeit zu entfernen und einmal ist mir dabei das Filament von der Spule gerutscht. Die zwei Grad Neigung sollten das verhindern.

Printer:

Turnigy Fabrikator mini V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0,1mm Layer Height

Infill:

I used 50% with PETG less will maybe also work

Notes:

I used PETG. 10% were to less. It didnt break but it was bendable.
50% PETG is may be a bit overkill :-D

comments.text: printed one with PLA and 30% infil. 1kg Spools are no problem, but you need a counterweight on the frontside of the fabricator, it tend to tumble. Ive put an old usv-battery on the top-front as counterweight and it works perfect ;)

author: ikarnovic

print_settings.Notes:: The center post is fragile. If it breaks off just glue the weights in or use VHB tape.

description.text:
A Tiko Motor Anti Backlash weight mod.
Based on the ideas of Pratyeka and his original mod
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2076518

I wanted to add 85grams or 3 Ounces of weight to each motor using off the shelf fishing weights, because I am cheap!

I bought these weights:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003QUQR94/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

$3.42 for 5 weights.

There are 2 parts.

(1) is the bracket used to hold the weights after they are cut in half
(2) is the holder used to make cutting the weights in half easier.

I cut the weights using a simple metal cutting hack saw, it was easy, I held the weight in the holder in a vise. It seemed to work quite well.
I simply friction fit the weights on the posts and the bracket on the motors. But come hot melt glue would probably be a good idea.

Name = GEORGE
BlockWidth = 2
Clouds that have Agustus and Hazel's saying, "Okay?" "Okay."
Small dog on it's sledge.

This is a small dog created by the Finnish interior designer Eero Aarnio. Because I liked its simplicity, I eventually recreated it in 3D. You may buy the real thing at https://www.finnishdesignshop.com/furniture-for-children-eero-aarnio-puppy-c-899_903_1008.html. I use the file to test my new color filaments. I completed it with a small sledge and with a small stick that fits in the sledge's front and end in order to connect and pull several sledges one after the other. If each dog with it's sledge is printed in a color several dogs may be aligned in a small "rainbow". I printed the dog, the sledge and the stick in PLA at 210°C with supports and brim on a Dagoma printer. There are also the STL versions without supports. Happy printing to all!

Handle I originally made for my Pittsburgh ratchet , but can also be use on other hand tools such as files, screwdriver, etc. All you need to do is all cut you desired shaft hole in the handle. Please feel free to post photos of your printed handles.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

highest possible setting

I took the bottle cap ant trap by Drelen, and modified it slightly for use without a bottle cap, since I don't really have anything with suitable bottle caps. I really liked the simple design with the cover to keep the rain out and the sun off the liquid poison so it didn't evaporate as quickly. I just added a bottom to the middle of the base and sloped it downward to make a little poison well the ant's can easily access. I use the name brand sweet borax liquid found at your local home store. Clean up and refill is easy enough with a little water.

Update - Ants have made a superhighway to the poison feeders. I've had to refill several times and the poison doesn't seem to affect the PLA at all.

title: Anker Powercore Mini+ Mounting Brackets
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Mounting brackets for a Anker Powercore+ Mini power supply. It was specifically designed to mount the power supply to my road bike. But it can be zip-tied to anything flat or tubular. It's V-block design is meant to be generic, and I made sure it was easy to print without supports. Future designs will likely revolve around improving the zip-tie zones. The fit should be a slip fit. But may require a little bit of force if there's too much deviation in the exterior coating. If that's the case you can scale up a percent or two to add clearance.

Update: V8 has improved zip-tip ribs.

Update: Added a hooded version to help protect the USB side from the elements

description.text:
This is a version of the geometric proof of the Pythagorean Theorem with a simplified design to aid assembly and avoid lost pieces.
Rather than just pegs that the pieces can slide off of or a top that requires manual intervention during printing I incorporated a pin connector so that the pieces can push down onto the pegs and not slide back off.
To aid in this mechanism I also slightly tapered the loop openings on the chain and square.

Most importantly I added labels to the proof. To aid in comprehension I added A^2, B^2, C^2 to their respective base areas, and A, B, C labels for each side of the triangle and the right angle symbol.

Notes:

Printing the base in high quality can be beneficial for the small pin connector features.

author: richgain

title: Bixler 2 Autopilot cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I didn't like the standard way of mounting my APM 2.5 in Bixlers so I decided to cut the foam out from the top of the fuse and put my autopilot there. It's a very nice position for getting access to it more easily and it's still right on the CG. This is a simple cover I designed to maintain the same airflow while allowing the APM to be placed there.
The cover fits fairly well and should be held on with blemderm or similar tape. It's 110mm long so only cut 100mm of foam out from the fuse. This design is directional and follows the fuselage shape to within .5mm.

Print standing up with no supports and 100% fill at 1 shell. I used semi-clear for effect but any color would do. Make sure you have a very well leveled and clean surface because there is minimal contact area to the build plate printing in that orientation.

title: wlan extender power case with tripod mount

description.text:
I use the popular combination of wlan extender tplink TL-WA830RE and powerbank XT-Power MP-10000 to extend the range of my perrot ar drone 2. This case attaches the powerbank to the extender and provides a mount for a tripodm so you can set it up at your starting place. Mounting your extender on a certain height improves the range as you move away from interference of the ground. you need:
a common tripod socket 10mm diameter.
maybe a liitle bit of glue

• print the parts (you need 2 knobs and 2 long pins)

  • attach the adapter to the extender using the knobs. put the through the holes in the adapterframe turn 90 degrees and put the into the holes for the wall mount of the extender. turn around 20 degrees, the adapter should now sit tight.

  • attach the powerframe to the adapter using the long pins. just stick them through, but be gentle and maybe use pliers to ensure the frame doesnt bend and break.

  • attach the tripod mount to the adapter. push the pin though the center hole . depending on your print you might need to sand the pieces a little, yu might want to secure the connections with a little glue. though it wasnt neccessary on my print.

  • push teh tripod socket into the hole in the mount piece. i recommend to hot glue this in, as it is the most vital part and you dont want your extender/powerbank just falling of the tripod.
    • thats pretty much it. put the powerbank in sideways, secure it with the clamp, connect the cable. have fun.

description.text: BONJOURS CETTE CHOSE EST UNE IMPRIMANTE 3D
CCSS

I decided to 3D scan my face, then put it up on Thingiverse. You can scan your own face by downloading an app for IOS called Trimensional. Of course, being a 99 cent app, there are large limitations. If you get it right however, you can get a pretty decent looking result. I printed it with 10% infill and a .1 mm layer height, and it turned out just fine. You could probably even go to .2 mm, but I would not go over that.

If you need more instruction on how to use the app, you have to first turn your brightness up all the way on your mobile device, and make the room you're in pitch black. Take a picture of your face and make sure that there is not any intense glares on your face. Just in case you're wondering, I have no correlations to the developers of the app, I just found it interesting, and easy to use for a beginner or someone who has a small budget, like me.

title: best 3D-printable bearing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These bearings are espacially designed for 3D-printing. These bearings don't use regular balls like other bearings but it uses specially designed for 3D-printing balls. This insures the most supple 3D-printable bearings with the least amount of play. The bearing prints in only one piece, fully assembled. You may have to wreck the balls a little lose after it has printed because the tolerances are very small. For the best result you can lubricate it with some grease. Hope you like it and can use it in your project. (results can depend on printer settings and type of 3D printer used).

I added a new 3D model of the small bearing to the file section called "homemade_printable_bearing_heavy_small_V3_easy_printable.stl" . With this model there is more space between the inner ring, the balls and the outer ring. This model should print more easy then the previous model but there will be more play between the inner and outer ring. This model is made for people who have trouble printing the first version. I'm sorry for this but I made the first version so my printer could print it without any problems. I didn't anticipate for the use of other printers. Hope this new model will be printable on most other 3D-printers.

dimensions bearings:
small bearing (V2 and V3): inner diameter = 12 mm
outer diameter = 40 mm
height = 12 mm

big bearing: inner diameter = 53 mm
outer diameter = 81 mm
height = 12 mm

video : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N2V0BuoXlf4

If you like my video leave a thumbs up and if you want to see all my video's and my future video's consider subscribing to my youtube chanel, it is free, doesn’t take much time and you are really helping me out by doing this. Thank you in advance!

Feel free to take a look at my other designs:
robot hand || bionic hand prosthesis prototype: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2838239
Mini 3D-printable crossbow: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2710472
8 legged spider robot: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2470882
3D-printable linear actuator: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783959

Have a nice day!

HE 3D reprap prusa I3

No

0.2mm

100%

comments.author: tommy2toes

comments.text: I'm really sorry to hear that tommy2toes. As I said before, I made the updated version for people who had problems printing the original versions. This version has indeed a lot more space between the inner ring, the balls and the outer ring. This to compensate for the people their printer who can't print the first version. I would suggest to fine tune your printer (for example: the amount of filament extruded must be perfect in order to get good results with this model, little to much and everything welds together) and try printing the original versions, because if you have that much slop in the updated version, you should be able to print the original one. When you print these, the balls will always be stuck (don't expect it to roll of right from the printbed) and you have to put some effort into it to get it moving. And if you want to get it to rotate as souple as in my youtube video, you really have to turn the bearing a lot. So all the rough edges from the balls are gone. I personally didn't have any good experiances printing the bearings with round balls. The balls tend to be not round enough and block when rotated. It was the reason I designed these bearings in the first place.

comments.text: Hi there, just want to add to the wild discussion. I printed the larger bearing on a TAZ5 with HIPS, using the medium quality HIPS settings and Cura. Then went into the garage: I will not go into the WD40 discussion but the first thing I found was a silicone lubricant of some sort. Now the bearing is running fine. Amazing design, just takes a little bit of patience. Unfortunately I found out I need a bigger bearing, so I will look at the customizable ones.

comments.text: You need to calibrate your extrusion multiplier. Do a print of a basic cube in vase mode with no top layers (or stop it mid print), and measure the wall thickness with a pair of calipers. It should be with .01mm of what's set in your slicer. So if you are using a .40mm nozzle you'll probably have your layer thickness at .48. You should adjust your extrusion multiplier till the wall thickness is as close to .48 (or whatever your setting is) as possible..
comments.author: SimonSolar2C

comments.text:
After further consideration I think it depends on the printer and material being used.
For example extrusion can be under different pressure and expand into gaps more or less depending on many variables- filament viscosity, temperature, Extruder settings. This hearing probably prints as is very well on expensive and or precisely calibrated machines.
Many models need tweaking to match the printer and tolerances between parts often need adjustment.
There is actually a very similar customizable version which allows you to set the tolerance to match the printer.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2437268

remixed_from.title: 8-Bit Link - The Legend of Zelda NES (Custom amiibo)

description.text:
This is a 8-bit style Legend of Zelda fidget spinner I made at the request of a friends son. There are 3 different styles, one for 1/2'' ball bearings or marbles, one for 608 beearings, and one for m12 nuts. Hoping they are well balanced, this is my first attempt at a fidget spinner. Thank you to the original artists who I remixed to make this.

UPDATE: Fixed the hex spinner, added marble spinner

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

100
Fidget Spinner. Bearings required. Snaps in.

print_settings.Notes:: Because it was created in cm rather than mm, you will need to scale it up to the right size, if there is any interest, I might upload some different sizes.

description.text: I needed a good container for my night-time medication, and all of the other dispensers on Thingiverse were either too small or did not have the day on them. Thus, I made this for personal use, and thought someone else might find it useful. I will probably create a version 2 in the near future, as I think there is a lot of wasted space in the current design.

Assembly

Just click the top into the frame and you are ready to go.

description.text:
This is a fidget spinner toy using fishing weights instead of bearings as counter weights. The weights are 16 grams each, while standard bearings weight 11 grams. With weights instead of bearings, the fidget spins almost twice as long. (This is not a rigorous comparison. There may be differences in bearings that are not accounted for.)

The caps are also different such that each cap has a pair of tabs that slide into the tabs of the other cap. There is a small (~1mm) shoulder on the cap to prevent interference with the spinner.

A standard 608ZZ Shielded 8x22x7 Miniature Ball Bearing is used in the center.

The weights are barrel shaped and measure ~16mm long by 14mm at the widest part of the "barrel."

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Using a 0.6mm nozzle

Fitting the bearings

if the bearing does not fit after printing, heating with a heat gun until just before the plastic begins to soften makes it easy to insert the bearing.

This is a redesign of a small bearing in the centre to obtain the 360 spin.

The spinner has been design in such a way that it cam be adaptable to a any hand any size, just download the sqrt file for solidworks and change the dimension on the sketch of the spinner . I have made mine as small as possible so i went with 35mm which fits nicely in my hand.

I think that having something that is small and that fit the anatomy of my hand helps to enjoy the toy even more ,because of the perfect fit .

I hope you guys enjoy it and have fun spinning .
New design will be posted on my Youtube channel
Mr Jefferson 105

title: Slide on belt clamp/belt end tpu 6mm

description.text: I designed this simple tpu slide clamp after not being able to find one. i also use the little one as belt ends to use the notches on the cr10 carriage Hope its useful.

Printer:

Creality cr-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

To install you feed belt in small side wrap around carriage or make a loop interlocking teeth and feed back into clamp, I found a little water on the belt helps getting it pulled back through but keep in mind it will be less grippy till the water drys, If using as belt ends i loop back about 5 mm of belt wet it a little and pull it into slider until flush with the end.

Enjoy
